importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article indicates the most recent update on the flooding crisis, showing the ongoing impact and response efforts in Mexico.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding event occurred during a recent period of heavy rainfall, emphasizing the sudden and severe nature of the disaster.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The death toll is rising, with 65 people still missing as of the reporting date.
The primary affected states are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death).
Significant numbers are missing: 43 in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) and President Claudia Sheinbaum led public updates on the disaster response.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rise and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Thousands of military personnel from the Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to deliver food, clean water, and aid.
Over 80% of electricity supply has been restored across the five affected states, with 263,000 users previously losing power.
Around 100,000 homes were affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappearing'.
Mexicoâ€™s meteorological alert system failed to issue warnings for the extreme rainfall, raising concerns about disaster preparedness.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Mexico, heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond have caused deadly flooding across five states, with at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The hardest-hit areas are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths). The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with over 280mm of rain. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to deliver food, clean water, and medical aid. Around 100,000 homes have been damaged, and 263,000 lost power, though over 80% of electricity has been restored. The government has raised concerns about its meteorological alert system, as no early warnings were issued for the extreme rainfall.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
